lines.text:
[after a cat-fight with a chorus girl]
Next time I'll give you a facial instead of a scalp treatment!
I'll fix you, ya little peanut!
Hank, did you see Queenie? What's the matter Hank, aren't ya happy? Wasn't Queenie great? Aren't ya proud of her?
Oh, of course, Eddie. I'm glad to see her make good. Oh, but, gee, we ain't never had to get by on our legs before.
Oh, that don't mean nothin', Hank. Those guys are not going to pay ten bucks to look at your face; this is Broadway!
Yeah, "Broad's way!"

[Last lines]
It's better to star in P-P-Pe-or, P-P-Pe - or, Osh Kosh than st-starve on Broadway.
That's a bunk!
Now, you listen to me, Stupid, I'll handle things. Yes, and I'll have you back on Broadway and in The Palace! In less than six months.
No foolin'?
Why, it's cream in the can, baby.
Su-Su-Sure it is. Cre-Cre-Cre. It's, it's in the can!
[the Stage Manager is yelling at the electricians in the theater rafters]

[pointing to the stage]
I told you, I want a spotlight *right here*!
[a miffed electrician drops a spotlight off the rafters. It lands on the stage with a crash]

[cowed]
Thank you.
Gee, this is elegant, ain't it!
Oh, honey, with your looks and my ability, Oh, I wouldn't steer you wrong. Oh, now, don't worry. You see that electric sign with the fella in BVDs?
Yeah.
Well, right there, they're going to have the Mahoney Sisters.
In BVDs?
Yes, in BVD - Baby, they were plenty smart when they made you beautiful.
Come on, let's get cleaned up before Eddie gets here. I'll run a tub for you.
Oh, nothing doing. We're in New York to stay!
S-s-say, say listen, girls, you I-I know this town better than you do. And-and there are more sisters doing their acts over the lunch counters in New York, th-th-then over the - than in the theaters.
Oh, you're just a crepe hanger!
Well, we aren't leavin' this town, 'til we get a flash of Babe Ruth and Grant's Tomb.
Oh, goodbye Uncle Jed.
If you wanna see me, just call me up.
Yeah, fine. You're in the phone book?
You-you bet!
Queenie! All grown up and everything!
You see, that sisterly kiss won't be so hard to take now, will it?
I'll say it won't!
[Eddie kisses Queenie]
Take it big.
I did!
Gee... you were a funny looking thing when I first saw you, with those gangly legs and freckles. But, you certainly turned out to be a beautiful girl!
Oh, I'll go get some clothes on.
"Mrs. Eddie Kearns" - sounds pretty doesn't it?
Swell, Eddie!
Yeah, and you can feature that anytime, in the electric lights.
Wait! Wait a minute! Wait a minute! Wait a minute! Listen, toots, what's the matter with the left leg?
Well, I've got a headache.
Well, go on, sit down, take a load off your mind.
Say, maybe we better get undressed. Come on.
In a minute, I'm gonna lay that dame like a roll of linoleum!
And don't forget, we do things intimately.
[Wink]
Say, you've been asking for trouble and now you're gonna get it! You great, big, peroxide-headed, dizzy blonde, you! What are you thinking of that!
Oh, dear, I'm just shaky all over!
Oh, Queenie, will you stop. You're gettin' me nervous now. It ain't gonna be a bit different than it was in Reading, PA and we're going over just as big!
Oh... do you think so?
Why, it's cream in the can, baby.
You think it's a good show then, Zany?
It's just an oil well, that's all.
Alright, let's see your gusher.
Looks like a mine to me, from all the gold diggers you got in the troupe!
One more crack from you, bimbo, and you'll be holding a lily!
Listen, Mahoney, we want you up on the prow of that boat. Come on now. Take, get your clothes off.
Oh, but, I don't want to take my clothes off!
You were great Mahoney!
I'll say you were! You'll be riding in a Rolls Royce by Thursday!
[laughter]
What a flock of Johns will be waiting at that Stage Door.
Go on! You can't kid me!
I'm not kidding you. I may be there myself!
[More laughter]
Say Hank, do you think that's all I'll get to do? Go on without any clothes on?
Well, not if I can help it. But, you don't need to worry. Say you got a lot more on when you ain't got anything - from most of the dames I've seen around here!
Yeah! Well, I guess I'll go get undressed again.
Well, let's go and get a bowl of chop suey and we'll rewrite the show!
Well, if you'll write me back in the show, I'd go for a bowl of anything.
Well, you can - get most anything out of a bowl of chop suey.
Oh, Eddie, don't be such a crab!
Why do you let a guy like that hang around you?
Say, will you lay off him! I'm sick of hearing you crab all the time!
I'll give him a sock in the nose!
You and how many others?
I'm going to give her the swellest party she's ever had! Oh, Eddie, I love her so much!
You sure are regular, Hank.
I brought the radio along with me.
What can you get with that?
Why, gee, I can get Chicago with that?
Chicago? Why that's nothin'. I got Scotland last night.
How do you know you got Scotland?
Why, I heard the guy singing "The best things in life - are free".
I'd like to do a lot of things for you Queenie. How would you like an apartment, all your own? Say, on Park Avenue? And a car, all your own? Perhaps a Rolls Royce? Oh, and a lot of nice things.
Come on, little love boat, let's have this dance.
Say, what kind of a sap are you, anyway?
What do you mean?
Are you gonna let a John like that steal her away from you because he's got a little more Jack?
You're a coward! You're afraid of Jacques Warriner! Or, you'd go out and fight for her! But, you're just yella!
You think I'm yella, heh?
Sure, you're yella!
Well, I'll show you how much I'm yella!
Well, you're yella! You hear me! You're yella!
I'm yella, heh?
Yella! I said you are! You're yella! You're yella! You hear me!
Listen, there's gonna be no part in your show for that dame! Get me?

[Instructions to the piano player]
Now, give us a pick-up for an introduction and a couple of choruses. And swell to the finish. But you follow us, not us you.
